content: In this exercise, with \( T \) defined by \( T(\mathbf{x}) = A\mathbf{x} \), find a vector \( \mathbf{x} \) whose image under \( T \) is \( \mathbf{b} \), and determine whether \( \mathbf{x} \) is unique.\[	extbf{3. } A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 & -2 \-2 & 1 & 6 \3 & -2 & -5\end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{b} = \begin{bmatrix}-1 \7 \-3\end{bmatrix}\].

In this exercise, assume that \( T \) is a linear transformation. Find the standard matrix of \( T \). \\( T : \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2 \) rotates points (about the origin) through \( \frac{3\pi}{2} \) radians (counterclockwise).

Determine the dimensions of \( \text{Nul } A \) and \( \text{Col } A \) for the matrices shown in this exercise\[A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 3 & -4 & 2 & -1 & 6 \0 & 0 & 1 & -3 & 7 & 0 \0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 4 & -3 \0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0\end{bmatrix}\].
Find an LU factorization of the matrix\[\begin{bmatrix}6 & 9 \4 & 5\end{bmatrix}\].

In $\mathbb{P}_2$, find the change-of-coordinates matrix from the basis $\mathcal{B} = \{1 - 3t^2,\ 2 + t - 5t^2,\ 1 + 2t\}$ to the standard basis. Then write $t^2$ as a linear combination of the polynomials in $\mathcal{B}$.
Solve the linear algebra problem in this image
Solve the linear algebra problem in this image
Solve the linear algebra problem in this image
Solve the linear algebra problem in this image
Solve the linear algebra problem in this image
